item.title: Digital divide in Education: Policy lessons from the pandemic
item.dc:creator: sushantasubedi
item.content:encoded:
Following the lockdown, schools and universities shifted to remote learning overnight. After an initial difficulty in adapting to online zoom calls, the fortunate among us had the comfort of having online lessons from our own study desks. However, while a shift to online learning offered greater flexibility for some, it has posed a disproportionate challenge to nearly 1.6 billion children lacking access and ability to use information and communication technology.  

The digital divide and the homework gap

“Digital divide” or the gap between those who have access to internet and those who do not is not a new term. In the domain of education, this divide translates into homework gap: the divide between those who have computers and internet for digital learning at home and those who don’t. While this lack of access is partly due to geographic challenges to install required infrastructure for high speed internet, the more pressing issue is the socioeconomic digital divide: between the ‘have’ and ‘have-nots’ of digital means to learn.

According to OCED Data, the homework gap is persistent across regions in developed countries of the Global North, and more so between the countries in Global South and North. Nevertheless, the nature of homework gap varies. While using and utilising technology for education is an issue of concern for majority of the developed nations; for much of the Global South, there is a more fundamental problem of access. The access to internet and computer, let alone for education, is very limited for much of the Global South and the pandemic has just reflected and exacerbated this problem. For instance, despite having one of the worst regional inequalities among the developed nations, 95% of British children still have access to internet and computers. Meanwhile only 41.6% in Colombia, and a mere 12% in Nepal have that privilege. Consequently, despite the interregional digital inequality still being a concern for developed nation like the UK, the digital inequality in education between the Global North and Global South, is a more severe challenge.

Recent UNCTAD report has recognised that the LDCs are the most vulnerable to the homework gap, as 4 in 5 people lack access to internet during the time of pandemic. This lack of access limits the learning possibilities for children, and disproportionately to those from disadvantaged backgrounds, as schools and libraries are closed. While the lockdown is still being enforced  in much of the Global south, these children will have a disparate deficit in learning than their counterparts in the Global north. The impact on their general wellbeing is even greater, despite it being harder to fathom. A loss of nearly half a year of learning due to pandemic is hard to compensate, but the silver lining for countries should be that they take this pandemic as an acknowledgement of inequalities in education and shift their policy priority in tackling them.

What the future holds?

A new analysis from UNCTAD shows that the crisis has accelerated the digital solutions, and this landscape is likely to be continue in education sector as the economy starts to pick up. Scholars believe post-pandemic era to be an opportunity to transition into better and universal education through maximum use of digital means: like online lectures. However, while the use of digital means in education is likely to accelerate, policymakers should make sure those who can’t quite catch the pace should not be left out.

Policy lessons

The pandemic has brought a sense of urgency to problem of the homework gap and, on a wider vantage point, the socioeconomic digital divide. When we return back from the ‘new normal’ to the physical locations of universities and schools, this will not, however, ascertain the end of disparity. Hence, the post-pandemic education policy should prioritise and accentuate the need to ‘bridge the digital divide’ in education when countries look to press the ‘great reset’ button after the pandemic.

While multinational organisations like UNESCO has started to support, disadvantaged through introduction of several innovations in digital platforms in education; this solution, although encourages utility to the digitally connected, is not viable to those who lack access. Hence, to solve the problem of problem of access, public investment from government is crucial: through a greater spending in internet and digital infrastructure as a share of GDP.

However, debt accumulated during the pandemic is likely to make this harder for countries in the Global South, as spending is likely to squeeze in near term. Hence, debt relief for the LDCs, as some leaders suggest, could be an alternative to free up resources for digital investment in education. Nevertheless, as the homework gap is a global problem (a regional problem for some countries, and a national problem for some), it requires international solutions in the long term. Hence, the post pandemic world should strive to achieve a collaboration, through multinational organisations (private, public and non-governmental), to tackle the digital divide in education.

item.title: Foreign aid: reorienting its priorities
item.dc:creator: sushantasubedi
item.content:encoded:
Foreign aid is a contested topic in fields spanning economics, development and public policy. After nearly a decade of the great debate on the foreign aid, academics and general public alike are still divided on whether aid is effective: some go even further to assert that aid is not just ineffective, but also harmful. Evidence concerning the efficacy of foreign aid has been largely inconclusive, often because it is difficult to rule out reverse causality- whether it is foreign aid that has enabled progress or is it that countries which progress utilise foreign aid more. Consequently, till today, we don’t know whether foreign aid is effective. The pragmatic move is to manoeuvre foreign aid debate from whether it is effective to how to make it effective.

Transcending the 'foreign aid debate'

Advocates of aid argue that foreign aid is effective if delivered through innovative institutions.  Nevertheless, the catch here is innovative: often the institutions of the recipient countries are extractive and prone to corruption. Hence, foreign aid is less likely to be an effective intervention when it reaches the ground root. In fact, evidence from Easterly shows, that there has been a decline in growth rates in the decade when foreign aid was deployed.

In contrast, critics of foreign aid assert that either aid is less effective, or even malign. Essentially, the argument from the right argues that foreign aid crowds out the market. Meanwhile, the scholars on the left argue that it hampers the organic evolution of socioeconomic processes of recipient nations. Meanwhile, all these arguments share a common ground: the way foreign aid is delivered matters more than the foreign aid itself. Hence, the aid debate should rightly shift to how it can be made more effective.

Succinct story of foreign aid

Foreign aid that started nearly 6 decades ago has evolved over years and its priorities and direction of flow have changed. Initially what started as a support for economic development for the post-war Europe transformed into a diplomatic lever for geostrategic interest and, now the focus has been on building social infrastructure in the recipient countries. Another fundamental change has been the transformation of old recipients into new donors and the emergence of South-South coalition. Nevertheless, for the recipient countries, the story has remained the same: a loss of autonomy in its political, economic and social processes. Hence, after nearly 6 decades since the inception of foreign aid, as a system, and nearly a decade of the ‘the great aid’ debate, it is time to rethink the priority of aid: because foreign aid is here to stay!

What Next?

Foreign aid’s vices or virtues, delivered and institutionalised in current from, has been inconclusive despite pedantic econometric studies using Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA). Hence it is time to recalibrate our focus from what may work to what actually works. The question then is what actually works? An ardent alternative is seed funding.

Seed funding, for entrepreneurship novices like me, is where an investor invests capital in start-up for a part of the stake of an enterprise. However, unlike the conventional seed fund funding, the one delivered through foreign aid will have two disparities. Initially, there is not stake involved from the investor, because the capital raising process involves foreign donors, not investors. Secondly, the investment is fundamentally on social enterprises. Integrating these two conditions, the new nature of foreign aid  looks more like impact investing rather than power asymmetric transaction from the hegemonic donor at the expense of recipient countries.

The merit from this sort of aid stems from the fact that it galvanises local innovation within the recipient countries. This also ensures that the social impact is scrutinised, and sustainability is ensured in the entire process. Similarly, as the priorities and goals are often set by the social enterprises themselves, the power dynamics of foreign aid changes. The donors are unable to use foreign aid as means for geopolitical, strategic, and sometimes even malign intentions, but rather as an act of pure altruism and goodwill. This is because, this mode of delivery in foreign aid system is not mediated by the fragile states of the recipient countries, but innovative start-up founders. Nevertheless, there is a disproportionate representation of elite socio-economic class who represent these start-ups causing socioeconomic inequality in recipient countries. One alternative to resolve this could be to prioritise first generation founders rather than those who come from a more privileged background.

In addition, there is a fundamental challenge on achieving collaboration from the myriad of sectors involved in this form of seed-funding and impact investing. This stems from the fact that actors involved, both from the donors and recipient sides, like NGOs, private donors, and philanthropists have different structures, incentives, and policy priorities. Nevertheless, initiatives like Impact investment collaborative which engages experienced professional to mediate this collaboration could be a viable solution.

Takeaway message

To conclude, foreign aid has had a long history of controversy over its efficacy, priorities and direction of its flow. Nevertheless, the aid system is here to stay and a viable alternative to make it effective is to recalibrate its priorities and align them to support social enterprises in recipient countries through impact investing and seed funding. This new wave of thought has already gain considerable ground in foreign aid agencies and organisations in few donor countries. Evidence points that these beginnings have proven impactful for many recipient countries. Hence, the future discourse on the foreign aid, in the policy circle, should emphasis on making this idea more pervasive.

item.title: Evidence for policymaking
item.dc:creator: sushantasubedi
item.content:encoded:
If we sift through the history of the London School of Economics (LSE), we can find an interesting account of finalising its motto: “rerum cognoscere causas”, translating to ‘to know the causes of things’. As, a school founded by the people who believed that “solving social problems required hard thinking”, the motto for a premier social science institution was apt not just for its inception, but it also transcended well into the present times. This legacy has been brought into limelight in the 2019 Nobel Prize in Economics, where winners (Duflo, Banerjee, and Kremer) were awarded “for their experimental approach to alleviating global poverty”.

Evidence-based policymaking

Indeed, “modern problems require modern solutions” !

Even though evidence-based policymaking is not a new term, there has been a burgeoning interest in policy and practice to use rigorous evidence to inform the policy process in the last few decades. This has rightly shifted the traditional pattern of using anecdotal accounts and individual opinions to determine social and public policy into a more informed rational decision making process. The policymaking sphere, albeit little, now accepts and deploys rational research that guides its decision making in many countries: for instance, Behavorial Insight Team in the UK.  Nevertheless, one should be mindful that evidence is just a mean to inform the public policy rather than an end to determine a goal. Aside from rigorous synthesis of multitude of quantitative and qualitative evidence, policy making process is influenced by range of other factors, like state capacity, and institutions for effective interventions.

The ‘silver bullet’ or not really?

Even though use of evidence provides a clear direction to policy, there is plethora of evidence that needs to be considered. As a result, it is hard to judge which evidence is academically reliable, and ethically viable to adopt. Besides, there is also possibility of manipulation and fabrication of results, which a layman working in public sector might find hard to critically analyse. This stems from the fact that evidence sought for policy is often objective, and hence statistical analysis is hard to decipher if not communicated well. Apart from the complexity, there is also question of veracity (whether data is independent of biases or it is cherrypicked): Mark Twain rightly said, ‘there are three kind of lies: lies, damned lies and statistics.’ Subsequently, even though evidence and data driven public policy provides a rational alternative to policymaking, it is also prone to methodological flaws in interpretation and practice.

In the dominion of evidence-based policymaking, one that quite clearly dominates the field is Randomised Control Trials (RCTs). This is where two different groups, control and treatment groups, are either not given or given an incentive/intervention, respectively, and their outcomes/trend is analysed and compared later. This is how it looks like in graph, and this is how it sounds when used in society to fight poverty, and this is what it brings when used persistently and acutely! Nevertheless, RCTs and “randomistas” have been criticised within the academic circle, chiefly from the ethical vantage point: whether experimenting people is ethically justifiable. In addition, there have been critics on whether the outcomes of RCTs are externally valid: are they transferable beyond prevailing social, institutional and environmental contexts? Hence, while a silver bullet to some, RCTs has been a cautionary tale for others. The paradox is we will probably need post-RCTs' evidence to find out whether RCTs actually worked!

So what?

In the end, to know the causes of things does require intricate investigation and the use of scientific evidence on different facets relating to society. In this regard, evidence-based policymaking has some promising insights and applications in solving problems pertaining to public policy and development. Nevertheless, its application requires prudence, and more often than not, pure common sense. The sensible thing to do is to evaluate and synthesise evidence based on individual cases and contexts and use it to design public policies. I assume that would do an adequate justice to the school of thought that envisioned the role of hard thinking required to solve social problems.

item.title: Is poverty a choice?
item.dc:creator: sushantasubedi
item.content:encoded:
What is poverty?

In common parlance, poverty is defined as not having enough resources or income to fulfil one’s fundamental needs. Limiting poverty to just the definition of lack of material resources is problematic for its holistic and conceptual understanding. Scholars recognise that, alongside lack of resources, poverty has implications on power asymmetry and social exclusion in society.

Amartya Sen recognising this complexity quotes, “Poverty is not just lack of money; it is not having the capability to realise one’s full potential as a being.” While here, Sen is referring to capability approach- where people are deprived from leading a life they value due to lack of resources, he is implicitly highlighting the moral significance of being excluded from society. Following this line of argument, the absence of cash restricts the economic choices that people have and limits their engagement in society. For instance, a cash poor child may not be able to join a sports program at school- which excludes him/her with some potentially enriching social experience (or he/she could turn out to be next Leo Messi or Naomi Osaka).

The choice of people? Or the choice of the state?

The poverty puzzle is often linked to a choice taken by people. This belief subscribes to the fact that if people worked hard, stayed at school longer or did not have children if they could not afford them, they would overcome poverty on their own. Further, they even believe that poor are poor, because the entity intended to help them- the state, creates disincentives for them to work hard. This is often called poverty trap- where people are stuck in vicious cycle of poverty due to lack of initial thrust to escape poverty because this would mean giving up on benefits provided by the state. However, it is important to question: if poverty was a choice that one could escape- who, on earth, would not make that choice? In fact evidence shows that poverty trap does not exist!

An alternative belief espouses that poverty is a structural problem, beyond an individual one, and that the poverty is a choice taken by state and its political arrangements. This line of argument stems from the fact that if state would take the problem of poverty seriously- it could potentially solve it. However, state chooses not to focus on solving it, and times does not even understand poverty in its entirety.  UN’s special rapporteur Philip Alston, argues that governments use indicators of absolute poverty, dollar(s) a day measure, (as it shows that we have overcome poverty significantly) to justify their policy shift away from resolving poverty to other policy priorities.

However, the absolute idea of poverty doesn’t encompass the ‘social exclusion’ or the ‘relative deprivation” element of poverty’s definition. This entails understanding the idea of relative poverty, which measures poverty based on how close one is to the median income in that country/context. Based on this, the state is making an “uninformed” choice: without understanding multifaceted social nature of poverty that only relative poverty (knowing how well one is compared to median income can reflect inclusion/exclusion better) can reflect . Maybe, it is time for the states (who do not use the relative measures) to update their choices.

Why should states make a choice to solve poverty?

In her iconoclastic book, Kate Raworth argues that a prosperous society builds on a strong social foundation (with an ecological ceiling). For a strong social foundation, state should invest primarily on its people- the pool of untapped human capital potential that poverty disempowers. This requires a greater investment on education and health, among other things. This investment is not, however, a competing substitute for growth. Solving poverty can be taken as a long-term social investment strategy to foster the economic growth in the long run. How exactly? The technological change, which is the driver of economic growth, and likely to be so in future, will require more pool of skilled labour. An earlier investment in people, especially those in destitution, is hence necessary to make sure the human capital can be a reliable engine to facilitate growth.

Nevertheless, for many states, growth indicators is in a top priority as it hinges on the idea that economic growth will eventually create new jobs and possibly overcome poverty. However, evidence indicates that this is not quite the case - the returns of growth often gets accumulated to the top decile of earners rather than trickling down to the bottom decile. Hence, solving poverty requires some form of state intervention through investment in education and health, in short term, and redistribution in the long run. This is the only pragmatic choice to solve poverty, albeit an audacious one.

item.title: On reading ‘The boy at the back of the class’
item.dc:creator: sushantasubedi
item.content:encoded:
When one thinks of back of the class, we think of backbenchers- cool kids who sit at the back and do naughty stuffs. However, this boy at the back of the class, in the book, is not one of them. He is Ahmet- a refugee from Syria who comes to a new school in a new country and tries to adapt to both.

Called ‘the boy with the lion eyes’, Ahmet's story is told by a narrator who is in the same class as Ahmet, and eventually tries to befriend him. While written by Rauf for the children, the message of the book transcends across the politics around migration (so, not a bad read for adults). I won’t go into the details of the story, because the book is a very easy read and you can read it for yourself quickly. But here are two quotes I loved and managed to take a note:

  • “The best book leaves you with more questions than answers. Dad used to say, the more questions you ask the cleverer you will be...”
  • “You should never be horrible to someone who is being horrible to you, said mom, otherwise they win by making you just as bad as them.”

Words of praise:

In the book, Rauf sees the world around through eyes of a nearly 10-year-old narrator (9 ¾ to be precise). The characters including the narrator, Ahmed, and narrator’s friends come out as real person, who we might have encountered in our school days. The detail of these characters and the consistency of how they behave in the book gives a book ample verisimilitude. Similarly, the interactions between the characters are very organic- like how a normal person would speak.

Aside from the writing style, the author does a great work of bringing the sensible topic of refugee inflow happening in the developed world to limelight. It is important for children, and young adults alike, to get exposed to these critical social issues that matter. Rauf does this with an extraordinary flair crafting a story of adventure, fun and kindness. While her writing is very simple, the topic she raises- refugee crisis- should not be taken with triviality.

The author, in an interview, said that she was inspired by her encounter with a refugee child while working as a volunteer. Then, she began the arduous task of writing the book while she was bedridden due to illness- what a blessing in disguise! Also, the news of Alan Kurdi, a refugee kid who drowned while crossing the border through sea, was paramount to give her an impetus to come up with the book.

Final thing: the book, in two words, is exceptionally empathetic and imaginative. You would not be disappointed being the 10-year-old narrator while you follow the book as him/her; the writer does a great job of keeping the gender of the narrator a mystery till the end. To find more things to appreciate, read it for yourself.
